p: Many medicinal plants are used in beekeeping, some as nectar flows, others as additives for enriched honey [ 4, 5]. Goldenrod honey is considered to be particularly valuable in Poland, it is especially recommended to treat genitourinary system problems, its antioxidant activity is comparable with honeydew honey [ 6]. Beekeepers, when producing enriched honey and herbal honeys, often use herbal additives based only on their own sense and experience, without taking into account the possible negative effects that could be caused by excessive consumption. A particularly controversial plant is tansy (not admitted by the EU as a food additive due to their use in no alimentary fields [ 7]) and yarrow (containing bioactive component thujone, similar to tansy). Overdosing on these herbs may result in adverse effects, such as allergic reactions and dermatitis (yarrow) and abortifacient action (tansy) [ 8, 9]. Toxic doses of these herbs have not yet been established for humans, only LD 50 values for mice (oral administration) were reported: for T. vulgare 9.9 g/kg and for A. millefolium 1.5 g/kg of body mass [ 10, 11].
